1. What is Fourier series?
a) The representation of periodic signals in a mathematical manner is called a Fourier series
b) The representation of non periodic signals in a mathematical manner is called a Fourier series
c) The representation of non periodic signals in terms of complex exponentials or sinusoids is called a Fourier series
d) The representation of periodic signals in terms of complex exponentials or sinusoids is called a Fourier series*

Fourier series representation of a periodic function. Where n is the integer sequence 1,2,3,... In, E, av , an , and bn are known as the Fourier coefficients and can *be found from f(t). The term ω0 (or 2πT 2 π T ) represents the fundamental frequency of the periodic function f(t).

Let me tell you my story: once upon a time someone older told me "the square wave has all the frequencies" (later I learned it to be wrong). That same person played acoustic guitar and taught me that if I plucked the strings close to the head I could produce a electric guitar sound. Cool!

Time passes and I learn about standing waves ... I also learned that a string on an acoustic guitar can only vibrate with certain frequencies. How strange ... I hear different sounds but the frequencies are the same! If I can produce all sorts of different sounds with a string that vibrates always on the same frequencies ... could I produce a square wave? could I produce any signal?

Guess what: yes! The only problem is needing an infinite number of oscillators. See, guitar strings, being rendered static on both ends can only vibrate in frequencies that have nodes on both ends - frequencies that relate to the harmonic series. Harmonic series described by a guy called Pitagoras who was working guess on what? On a single string instrument.

"But Teacher, when I run this app on my phone I see a lot more frequencies!". Well, little grasshopper ... what you are seeing is called Fast Fourier Transform and has a window and other complications; Fourier series represent only repetitive signals that exist since before time and into after the future.

Now let's go back to our story.

I noticed a pretty interesting thing at around 6:40

So I do a TON of vector animation professionally, and I immediately recognized the way that the harmonic "wipers" were slowly assembling all of the correct curves to form the image. That's EXTREMELY SIMILAR to how Adobe Flash/Animate actually render the individual lines that are drawn with the brush.
Back in the Flash 8 days, I imagine that the way Flash would render brush strokes would be taking the raw pixel data and try to recreate the curves using the fourier series in a similar way to how Doga drew the Smarter Every Day logo. Flash has the same type of behavior when you attempt to draw a really long stroke with lots of curves in it.
Adobe changed Flash to Animate, and upgraded the brush so now it follows your input really closely with a ton of accuracy. I've noticed a significant change, and now that the lines have become extremely smooth, the actual time taken to render each stroke is quite long. That might mean that they're calculating the stroke with a ton of harmonics so that the strokes get REALLY SMOOTH, but now becomes more demanding on performance.

Therefore, we were required to make a 1st + 3rd + 5th harmonic approximation of a square wave using free running sine signal generators stacked on top of each other with a signal combining network output to an oscilloscope. It was maddening to hold them stable enough at low frequencies so we could take a picture for the lab report.

Fourier series has some limitations representing impulses but can be extended using the integral form (infinite number of frequencies in any interval which is more useful than it sounds) and windowing...multiplying the function to be approximated by a function 'window' like an exponential before doing Fourier analysis. I don't think there are many instructors who can seat the concept firmly in a students mind so that, for example, the student is not flabbergasted to find LaPlace transforms can solve physical system time behavior but also reveal the frequency response at the same time. They don't see this method as a form of Fourier analysis (and maybe missed the superposition idea). Anyway, it's easier to use SPICE computer network analysis...and I do.

As an interesting aside : a few decades ago there was a lot of interest in how simple systems could produce chaos. There was an adage coined at the time " three makes chaos ". It refers to a system in which a second pendulum is added to a simple pendulum, then a third pendulum is added to the second. If a two pendulum system is driven at constant speed the second pendulum will behave in a harmonic manner. If however a three P system is driven at constant speed the behaviour of the system will become chaotic. Science novelty stores used to sell nifty models reproducing this effect.
Applying a thought experiment to the graphic simulations can we imagine that they would show chaos as in a real dynamic system ? If no chaos is observed then why not ? Conversely we can ponder the question why in the real world do systems descend into chaos very soon ?

Actually a math and physics student at Georgia Tech doin research in PDEs which uses a lot of Fourier analysis. There is actually a cool relationship between what functions can be represented by a Fourier series. Such functions are called L2 functions and essentially they are the set of functions whose square is integrable over some domain. So most everyday functions can be represented via Fourier series, but if the function is not square integrable, the traditional Fourier series will not always converge. (Note: there are ways to extend the Fourier series to non-L2 functions, but this is a lot more complicated and general than just a sum of sine waves) This is really cool and related to a field of math called functional analysis which describes how different functions can be represented in terms of other functions.

It depends on what you mean "create any other function". So this is false in two ways.
It depends what you mean by "approximate any other function". For example You can't approximate a "square-wave" uniformly by adding sine waves and this is because the former is discontinuous, whereas the latter is not, and since the space of continuous functions from [-π,π] to R is complete with this metric. (So basically you'll always miss out on those edges). However, the up-shot, is that this works when you quantify approximation by meaning (on averge the varriance of the approximation errors, integrated over [-π,π] goes to 0) . This is latter statement is true since (in linear-algebra-esque terms:) "sine ways form a basis of L^2".
Second point: It depends what you mean by approximate "any function". For example, a non Borel-measurable function clearly cannot be approximated by fourier series.
General comment: Btw, he's not adding sine waves, he's shifting, scaling, and adding them. Otherwise, addings onely plain-vanilla sine waves will only get you another sine wave (to see this only requires basic trigonometry from highschool).

At first, I was a bit confused about what makes this visualization novel. It just seemed like a simple polar projection onto the Cartesian plane. But then, I sort of realized the point here, which is why I think it would have also been interesting to hear explained the conceptual implications behind the visualization in this video.

I'd like to take a crack at explaining. I'm only about 90% sure about this (for the love of god, correct me if I'm wrong), but this is my understanding: the Fourier series is comprised of a series of sine waves that add up to the periodic function under analysis. Each iteration (each sine wave) has a frequency that is n times a certain fundamental frequency (don't worry about what the fundamental frequency is; different fundamentals just result in scalar multiples of the function under analysis) and an amplitude that is determinable using the Fourier transform.

Now, the left-hand side of the visualization shows attached lines spinning. The big line in the middle is the first iteration of the Fourier series. The smaller line attached to that is the second iteration, and so on. Each line corresponds to one iteration of the Fourier series. Each line rotates at the same frequency of its respective sine wave, and each line has a length equal to the amplitude of its respective sine wave. At the end of the last line segment, a trace is drawn, in light blue. This trace is the polar representation of the function under analysis being approximated by the Fourier series. Then, it is projected onto the Cartesian plane, and this is the Fourier approximation of the function.

What I think is much more difficult to visualize is the relation between time domain and frequency domain (bode plots are in frequency domain). While this video was very cool, helpful, and educational, I think I personally yearn for a more visual and concrete understanding of how frequency domain can be visualized just by looking at a time domain function.

Overall, great video! It got me thinking, which means it served its purpose. I hope anyone who was curious about the Fourier transform learned much more about it from this video.

The fun bit is understanding how the Fourier integration works - how when you sum over all time the product between a sine wave and your function you get a magnitude which is your Fourier coefficient at that frequency. If your input is a sine wave and you graph the Fourier transform you get an impulse at that frequency. At the given frequency the result is infinite. As you wonder slightly to the side then over infinite time the errors add up and the result is zero. So the impulse is infinitely narrow and infinitely high and mathematically has an area equal to the magnitude of your sine wave.

Now that we have discovered the sign wave and function, lets see where this function is applied in the physical world. If your display on an oscilloscope a wave of electrical energy as seen on a antenna cable, often called standing waves or the pulse wave you would see in a TDR (Time Domain Reflectometer ) instrument, you will notice that you can find the same sine function based energy transfer in a wave of water that ripples across a still pond. If you were to put the water in a long square plexiglass tank and start a water in the tank, you could look at the water wave as it rippled along the tank wall and your would see a sine wave of water.
The same laws of physic and sine functions apply to both the electrical pulse and the wave of water. The only difference is the physical matter is different. In one case the physical matter is the mass of the water molecules and on the wire it is the mass of electrons.

Hey. There's a problem with doing that. Please look into "Gibbs phenomenon". You'll always have an error.. and it'll be higher in the edges (at points of more impulsive jumps or jump discontinuities). A square wave has jump discontinuities and sines are continuous functions. There's no way you can simulate square wave exactly using linear combinations of sine functions. You can only get an approximation.

As a math/science geek, the part I find really heartwarming is this: to generate all of those different waveforms, he is not changing the speed of rotation of any of the circles (they all rotate at integer multiples of the main circle; 2*, 3*, 4*...). The only thing he’s changing is the length of the segments in the “whip”... the sizes of the circles. Shorten a segment here, lengthen one there... and you’ve gone from a square wave to a sawtooth.

The "wipers" also represent a type of "linkage" mathematically speaking! But he's got a (very beautiful) graphical representation of the complex number version of a Fourier series. That uses Euler's formula e^(i t) = cos t+ i sin t so the series is \sum_ a_n e^{i n t}.
But this is actually just a Laurent series \sum a_n z^n since |z|= 1 (z= e^(i t) is on the unit circle) and since the series is biinfinite
(over n in Z the integers, not just the positive integers as in McLauren or Taylor series). If you add time to the visualization, the circle becomes a spiral. Very cool!

Extremely interesting. However - once again - it's the life story of teaching somebody something ..... or failing to teach somebody something properly. For example, at 2:23, he says 'add one more'. But the diagram doesn't show at all what 'adding one more' actually involves. So for n = 3, everybody merely sees a black-coloured circle with a some other exotic curve around the outside. That does not clearly show what 'add one more' means. It would be easier to just say add one more 'circle' having one-third of the diameter of the original circle, and put the centre of the new circle on the perimeter of the original circle. And the wiper associated with the new circle (with one-third diameter) will rotate around the centre of the new circle at three-times the speed of the wiper of the original circle. Nice video anyway.

I should probably point out that you don't "need" sine waves to create any of these wavefunctions. You can pretty much do it with any wavefunction given enough of them. I mean, you already need an infinite amount of them for sine waves so why not others right?

The true beauty of sine waves (other than being simpler mathematically) is that it is an eigenfunction. This makes it the perfect pure waveform that appears everywhere in the universe when working with these pure systems.

Hope this helps the curious people understand why we use sine waves, and sine waves in particular.

All schools should stop looking at sine and cosine functions as " Flat" functions that can be drawn on a plane, as they miss one dimension of the many dimensions in which many functions do exist. Sine and Cosine, each consist of the summation or the subtraction of two three dimensional rotation in opposite directions. If one makes it clear that the flat pulsating sine and cosine are only the projection of a three-dimensional function, life for students engineers would be so much simpler.
One should learn to visualize in three dimension e^( r+jwt) - e^rt*( cos( wt) + j.sin(wt) and the opposite rotation e^ rt *( cos( wt) -j.sin(wt) and one can see many beautiful images being created when handling Fourier, Laplace, Convolution Integrals and how filters operate with their impulse function operating on a kernel operating on an input signal. I asked him and he just  brushed it off saying that  all I needed to know was how it was derived mathematically and I could solve any problem that  was thrown at me. But what if I didn't want to solve a problem. What if the problem was that I wanted to know what it was that I was learning. It was a disappointing day. I eventually ended up dropping out of college because this trend continued throughout the year. Bear in mind, I was so passionate about computer science, I lived  and breathed it. I was no gifted genius but I really enjoyed. My teachers managed to suck out every last bit of passion I had for the subject  and drove me away from it. 10 years  on,  I'm happy with where I am in life but I can't help but wonder what could've   been. Nice.  I have reservations about calling the demo "helpful" for understanding the Fourier series/transform etc.  Doha definitely understands it, and that is why he was able to come up with the very clever circle analogy (by the way, I have seen this kind of analogy before).  But, in my opinion, this in no way helps understand the science/mathematics of the Fourier series/transform.  I am not trying to be "holier than thou", but to get a true understanding there are a few essentials things one needs to understand.  One key thing of which to be informed is that Doha could have used any "complete" set of functions (sinusoidal functions make up such a complete set, complete means all sinusoidal functions are "orthogonal", I won't get into the meaning, and Doha understands this, too) can be used to completely describe another function as a sum of the components within the complete set, with "different" amounts of each component depending on the function to be described. In that regard sines and cosines in the Fourier series are really not special.

Oh the old "jif" vs "ghif" thing again.

Yes, the first "g" stands for "graphical" but English doesn't use a hard "g" when followed by "i". If so, very rare.

If "ghif" is the correct pronunciation, the NATO should be Nah-tor. And that's "a" (represented by "ah", I can't think of no other way using the Roman alphabet) as in Atlantic and "o" as in the first letter of "organisation".

So BOOM. It's pronounced "jif". Unless you want to correct all the other acronyms that don't obey the pronunciations of how the letter is pronounced in the words they come from.

However, if you say "ghif" to me, I will not correct you. I will just roll my eyes internally at your inconsistent logic and faux-pedantic inaccuracy and keep saying jif. Or I will laugh at how we all have different perspectives and systems for navigating this crazy world and otherwise respond outwardly the same as the first option.

Great video, did a bit of digging on the subject and I discovered reference to a famous paper by J.W. Cooley and J.W. Tukey from 1965. Their work utilised Fourier analysis and led to a radical increase in computing speed by exploiting the binary notation inherent to computers and the symmetry of sine waves. This leap in computing power is what enabled the effective storage and recall of analogue recorded sound via digital bits of information.

You present a way of creating a wave function that could be applied to sound as well as 2D line. The "wiper" could serve as a value to a sampled sound, or sound from an instrument, and assigned to an effect. The effect, such as echo, delay, reverb, decay, noise and so on would be controlled by the value. The value would be how much of the effect is used. You can then mix wipers of finer and finer increments to create new values applied to the effects. There is no such thing right now as a Fourier Series as Midi controller, but I think if anyone can do it, it's you and Andrew Huang.

Hey, Destin! This reminded me of something I've seen in the realm of electronic music. There's a software synthesizer called Serum which, besides plenty of other bells and whistles, lets you design your own waveform via what I'd describe as a sort of Fourier bar graph. There are two rows of vertical slider controls; the top row lets you "dial in" sine waves at different harmonic frequencies — when all of them are maxed out, the result resembles a saw wave — and the bottom row's sliders push each of those sines more or less out of phase. Then, since it's a synth, you can hear what it sounds like! You might want to fiddle with the demo version a bit, and/or search YouTube for "Serum FFT editor". Take care, man!

I didn't realize until recently that graphing a summation of sinusoids in the time domain to approximate a function is the same thing as finding the frequency content of a signal. This is why square waves have a lot of harmonics and spectral content- because it takes a lot of sinusoids to approximate the square wave function in time domain.

If you are interested in pursuing Fourier analysis a step further... Try recording a word and running a transform on it. Then graph it as a spectrum. Then reconstruct it using the individual sin waves and magnitudes and play it back. If you record an annoying tone with your recording you can eliminate it when you reconstruct the sound. Also, note that the amount of data required to reconstruct a good replica of the original sound is much less than the original data. This is used in various forms of compression and audio recording. I think your viewers would be interested in seeing some of these things demonstrated and explained.

I wouldn't consider this using the Fourier Analysis, I would consider this more Convolution. The Fourier series is almost the exact opposite of this.

Think of the Fourier Transformation (Series whatever you want to call it) as a reverse blender. Giving this transformation any smoothie, it can tell you which ingredients made the smoothie. In Math/Engineering terms, giving this transformation, any signal, it can break it down into its frequency components. For example, I fed a song into a Matlab function that computes the Fourier Analysis on it. The function/graph I get out (Called a Power Spectral Density Function), shows me the main frequencies that were played. Obviously, some stick out more than others. When you look at the frequencies, we can pair them with notes. Using this Fourier Analysis, I was able to determine that D2 is the most played note in the Pink Floyd song "Another Brick in the Wall".

So when he is adding a bunch of functions together, he's starting with the ingredients and getting a smoothie, it's not "technically" the Fourier Transformation. If he was starting with the function that makes up the graph of the head and then using the transform to find the base signals, THAT would be the Fourier Transformation.

You see in your animations that adding the harmonics will not really give you the square wave. Those pointy ends on the corners will not go away as your add more of the wipers. Destin, there's even more science here! Isn't Doga's program a great visual aid for teaching people about deferents and epicycles?

For those who don't know, the stacked smaller cycles that Doga showed are the "deferent and epicycle" model in astronomy, the building block of the planetary motion model from Ancient Greece until the Scientific Revolution gave us ellipses. The astronomers over those many centuries used just a few stacked circle layers (the largest one called a deferent and the rest called epicycles) to predict the elliptical planetary motions to within their limits of (eyeball) observation. As you can imagine after seeing Doga's initial square wave demonstration, they did pretty well! Epicycles could even explain the apparent retrograde motion that astronomers saw in other planets, which gave them that #mathswagger if anything did. And circles fit well with the philosophy of the Greeks and later the monotheistic religions that that circles are perfect, and the Heavens are perfect, and look the Heavens run on circles, so Q.E.D.

Later in this video, Doga went even further and showed that with many epicycles, you can draw some pretty arbitrary shapes. Assuming you have computing power or Fourier math, that is! Not shown here, but with infinitely many epicycles you can truly draw any shape.

But Copernicus lived hundreds of years before computers and Fourier. This became an issue when Copernicus objected to one of Ptolemy's innovations, the equant, which Copernicus felt to be a departure from Aristotelean cycles and epicycles. To solve this aesthetic problem, Copernicus traded the equant for more epicycles, which rapidly became computationally prohibitive. He sat down and reformulated it from the ground up, and became convinced that the Sun had to be the center that everything else orbited around - not only did it make the math easier and more elegant than his first try, but it predicted physical properties like the ordering of the planets.

It's even more impressive because the crucial experiments proving that Copernicus was on the right track were only possible to conduct with Galileo's telescope, several generations later.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deferent_and_epicycle

I just wanna make one technical comment here, no big stuff, but, you can't just take "any" function and expand it into Fourier series. Dirichlet Conditions (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dirichlet_conditions) need to be satisficed in order to ensure the convergence of the series. You don't want your function suddenly go to infinity in any point of his domine. As I said, is just a technical stuff, but, inside this conditions, you can actually prove that the series will always converge. Regards.

Fourier transforms are also neat because it is the mathematical basis behind Heisenberg’s Uncertainty Principle. A waveform that has a lot of periods will have a narrow frequency band, whereas a waveform with fewer periods will have a wider frequency band. I.E. the more information there is about a wave’s position, the less there is about its frequency, and hence its momentum. Since all matter has wave-like properties, it shares this characteristic!

In my view, the real power of the Fourier series is the idea of a "complete orthogonal family" of functions. The standard Fourier series uses sine and cosine waves, but in general, we can use much weirder functions with desirable properties. For example, in the case of a Sturm-Liouville problem, we are able to solve a family of simple differential equations, then combine those solutions in a series to solve a more complicated one. Power series let us decompose a function into something resembling a polynomial, Dirichlet series let us decompose it into something with number theoretic uses, Fourier series let us decompose it into "signals," and orthogonal series representations are the next step of abstraction of this idea.

In acoustics, the Fourier series is a basic principle we learn about. There's one thing that is not entirely correct in this video, which is that you can create any wave with sine waves. The Fourier series only applies to periodic waves, i.e. waves that are unchanging. So, you can create square, triangle and sawtooth waves, but you couldn't emulate, say, a piano, with the Fourier series alone.

It's still freaking fascinating to think about.

He used two independent real-valued fourier transforms for the x- and y-components to synthesize the two-dimensional SmarterEveryDay-logo after asigning a "time-axis" along the graph.
This gives him four fourier-series in total as there are two closed curves to draw.
However, for a two-dimensional graph I would propose to use a complex valued fourier-transform which consists of superimposed positive and negative rotating complex phasors.
In the case of the SmarterEveryDay-logo there would be a total of two complex-valued fourier series.

Destin, you changed my way I look at the world. Today at launch a candle begun to flicker and I was wondering why. Upon further observation, it looked like the candle flame was periodically go up and down in intensity of flickering and has pauses in between. It was on a cycle of about 5 seconds and the peak flicker had an estimated frequency of 80hz while the flame shrunk to about 3.5cm during the idle phase and up to almost 10cm at peak hight.

It has the notion of two sine waves of slightly different frequency being added together, my estimation would be 80hz and 80.2hz or something which could be noise from the radio, our refrigerator or the dishwasher that was making a continuous sound.
